citations.narrative:
Some pig enclosures have an excessive buildup of excreta along the back walls of the enclosures, under enclosure gates,
and on toys hanging in the enclosure. Some pigs have feces on their rumps and legs. The licensee states that the pens
are cleaned before animals are placed in the pen and after they are transferred out, but it may be several weeks before
the pigs are transferred out and the pens are cleaned. The excess accumulation may lead to contamination of the
animals, spread of disease, odors and attract pests. Excreta must be removed from the enclosure as often as necessary
to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. When
enclosures are cleaned by hosing or flushing, adequate measures shall be taken to protect the animals confined in such
enclosures from being directly sprayed with the stream of water or wetted involuntarily.

The room in which medications and medical equipment are stored is not kept clean. The floor and walls of the room are
dusty. The outside of several bottles of medication has dirty brown areas. Needles and ear tags are stored uncovered in
cabinets with extensive dust. Medical equipment is stored on a dirty towel in the fridge.
Dirty surfaces create a disease hazard by potentially contaminating the medicine administered to pigs and attract pests.
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to
facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as
necessary to protect the health of the animals.

There were clusters of flies noted in enclosures throughout the facility, most noticeably on enclosure gates. No fly control
measures were observed. Flies can cause irritation to the animals and spread disease causing organisms. A safe and
effective program for the control of insects shall be established and maintained.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 25, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
Some pig enclosures have an excessive buildup of excreta along the back walls of the enclosures, under enclosure gates, 
and on toys hanging in the enclosure. Some pigs have feces on their rumps and legs. The licensee states that the pens 
are cleaned before animals are placed in the pen and after they are transferred out, but it may be several weeks before 
the pigs are transferred out and the pens are cleaned. The excess accumulation may lead to contamination of the 
animals, spread of disease, odors and attract pests. Excreta must be removed from the enclosure as often as necessary 
to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. When 
enclosures are cleaned by hosing or flushing, adequate measures shall be taken to protect the animals confined in such 
enclosures from being directly sprayed with the stream of water or wetted involuntarily. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The room in which medications and medical equipment are stored is not kept clean. The floor and walls of the room are 
dusty. The outside of several bottles of medication has dirty brown areas. Needles and ear tags are stored uncovered in 
cabinets with extensive dust. Medical equipment is stored on a dirty towel in the fridge.  
 
Dirty surfaces create a disease hazard by potentially contaminating the medicine administered to pigs and attract pests. 
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to 
facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as 
necessary to protect the health of the animals. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
There were clusters of flies noted in enclosures throughout the facility, most noticeably on enclosure gates. No fly control 
measures were observed. Flies can cause irritation to the animals and spread disease causing organisms. A safe and 
effective program for the control of insects shall be established and maintained.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 25, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
